body:
deleting projects typically doesn't refactor other projects which depend on the removed project. Removing those dependency declarations would have to be done manually, e.g using the projects properties window.

I quickly checked and this did remove the dependency correctly, even after the project was already gone
I think this is good to go as is. The exception backtrace is a 100% match into the right file. While I agree, that knowing the problematic file, this is IMHO not really needed for this hotfix.

> I think this is good to go as is. The exception backtrace is a 100% match into the right file. While I agree, that knowing the problematic file, this is IMHO not really needed for this hotfix.

the exception trace won't contain the file path which is causing the exception. To clarify the diff: the `i` is the `Indexable` method parameter. `i.toString()` would provide the path - this is no index or anything like that.
My focus is to get a new VC fast. We can discuss this longer, but from my perspective we gain little. I don't care either way. The fix is here and is mergeable, everything else takes more time.
I've tweaked the code to attach the message to the exception.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e9c76456-50e3-43a3-85e8-9120dd49fa85)
This is more what was looking for, the breadcrumbs are different from this. It shows the whole path from the beginning to the end,

yes I do understand the suggestion. It is semantically equivalent of the breadcrumbs bar, just with reduced functionality.

The main difference is that the breadcrumbs bar is listening to the cursor position. This would render the first line of the clipped block which doesn't fit in the viewport. However, realistically this likely would have to be implemented using a delayed action just like the breadcrumbs bar. So I don't see why it couldn't be used right away for this.
@neilcsmith-net, @mbien - Please review this PR whenever earliest its possible for you, along with any suggestions for improvement. Thank you.

Thanks, @mbien, @Chris2011.

I wasn't aware of the breadcrumb. It is close to what I was looking for, but not quite. Its location isn't optimal. For example, the search bar might buffer between the breadcrumb and the document:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d683eca6-0e9c-4b0e-8bd4-4aa4c9be8d85)

Having the option to move it to the top might bring it closer to what I had in mind.

Also, with [native CSS nesting](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_nesting/Using_CSS_nesting), the breadcrumb only shows the top level:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/95473354-15b4-4d2c-883b-ab5480bda2b9)

Is it by design or should I consider it a bug?

@asafm7 it is just not implemented. When it was implemented, there where no nesting in CSS. You can try scss also whether this is working or not. But it will be a new feautre request, instead of a bug.

Thanks, @Chris2011.

What about the option to change the position of the breadcrumb?

Thanks for your feedback. However, I think that the application behavior should be consistent with the user's expectations. If I want to delete the project, I know what I'm doing. A "typical" behavior should be offered as an option. I therefore suggest completely deleting references to the deleted project by checking a dedicated checkbox, normally not checked.

Sure, but as I said this not fixes the FR request for me either. We have the calculation of when a block goes out of the viewport we just need to stick this to the top. Adding option to move Breadcrumb around is a different FR.

my user expectation would be to not trigger a refactoring when a project is removed. The base project might not even be visible to the IDE. But I am going to add the contribution-welcome label in case someone would like to implement this feature for ant projects. Ant projects are from the era when dependencies were often just relative paths - so there is an argument to be made that removing project files actually removes the dependency if the base project is already open.

could you quote the pasted logs using code sections like I did for the other issue you posted? Selecting it and pressing the code button should work. It often breaks the markup and can be hard to read - thanks.

Tried NB 13 (the oldest one I've got around) with jdk-11. Didn't work.

The old package-info.java, where I _think_ completion worked, was put together in Nov 2020, around NB 12.1
rc4 online
Please retest with RC3/RC4 of NB24, if that does not fix the issue, please provide complete steps to reproduce.
Please check RC3/4 for NB24. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/discussions/7898

ran a brute force test which opens all NB projects and still got some exceptions

test:
```bash
# opens all netbeans modules as smoke test
# run in netbeans project, should be built first

NB="insert path"
JDK="insert path"

OPEN=$(find -maxdepth 2 -mindepth 2 -type d\
 -not -path "./.git*"\
 -not -path "./nbbuild/*"\
 -not -path "./dist/*"\
 -not -path "./ide/xml.core"\
 -not -path "./nbi/*" | sort | xargs)

FLAGS="-J-Dorg.netbeans.modules.parsing.impl.indexing.LogContext\$EventType.PATH.treshold=20"

"$NB" --userdir /tmp/nbusr$$ --jdkhome $JDK $FLAGS $OPEN
```
(will open >800 projects)

assuming @ebarboni has still sufficient willpower i would recommend to:
- revert the hotfix **and** original PR https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7982
- trigger rc5 (when convenient) without waiting the full week

> This may need a bit more, to avoid the `mainClass`/`mainFilePath` being re-computed in `NbLaunchRequestHandler`. 

Fixed. Thanks for pointing this out.

While I think this is probably a good solution, unless the original change is very important, I would suggest to go with Michael's proposal, and revert the original change (+the hotfix) from NetBeans 24, and re-apply to master.

I agree with @lahodaj  However, that revert will also sync to master, so the whole change from the original PR plus patches will need to be opened and reviewed again.  I've added `do not merge` to this, but ideally close and wait for @mbien @ebarboni to sync everything through.
will needs conflict resolution first.

Is my understanding correct, that you expect automatic transaction handling by using either EJBs or `@Transactional` CDI beans?

> For example, when creating a web application with maven and creating jsf page from entity, which causes the creation of JPA bean and CDI bean, the problem can be solved.

What are the steps to do this?
@ebarboni the conflicts should resolve itself once the hotifx (https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7983) is reverted

so I opened a PR for that too, if we revert in the right order everything should apply cleanly I hope:

1) https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7999
2) https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7982

I think reverting both PRs https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/7981#issuecomment-2504396145 might work without having to resolve conflicts.

We should avoid working on those files until this is resolved if possible - otherwise syncs back to master will cause unnecessary conflicts and/or PRs might show up multiple times on release notes.
no longer reproducible with nb23. sometimes it still happens, but no longer every time
ok doing the 2 PR merge , ant then creating the sync PR

The conflict is expected and discussed previously with @mbien (somewhere, Slack??)  Need to keep the spec version in master.

We _really_ need to stop having spec version increments in pull requests.  They're already handled in the release process cc/ @dbalek

Thank you!!!

ps: I am using NB 23, some files appears the error in line, one or two other files show the error at the tab title on top, but no at the line.
Is this in the context of adding to the IDE, or adding to a platform application?  Can you create a basic example project that demonstrates the issue, and attach it here.
Please retest with NB 24 RC: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/discussions/7898

Please retest with NB24 RC: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/discussions/7898

If it fails, please provide the IDE/messsage.log.
what should be done, add new PR to delivery to make the 2 sync PR to be valid?

No, this can't be done by a PR directly from delivery without causing problems.  Last one I handled was #6656 I think.

Bit of local git-fu needed.  Branch from master locally, merge delivery into it, handling the conflicts, open another PR from that into master.

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/8006 an attempt to resolve the conflict without touching delivery.

It clones **delivery** and edits the merge commit so that it is compatible with a merge back to master.

i guess a way to compare this is to diff both diffs
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/8003.diff
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/8006.diff
```
$ diff 8003.diff 8006.diff 
```
```diff
134c134
< index 7b0db0ba928e..00955b41faa0 100644
---
> index 7b0db0ba928e..3d7ce4d4ef2a 100644
142c142
< +spec.version.base=9.36.0
---
> +spec.version.base=9.38.0
```

Thanks for your quick response. I have installed/copied NB24-RC4 from
netbeans-24-rc4-bin.zip
<https://nightlies.apache.org/netbeans/candidate/netbeans/netbeans-24-rc4-bin.zip>
archive.
The bug with dialog "JSF Composite Component" still exists. Ide log file is
in attachment.

Best regards Stevan Berberovi

I originally wanted to do something like that but it didn't feel right, since this essentially lets the spec version go backwards in master and adds another commit which lets it jump forward again. (and if someone would look through the merge commits on master it will look like the same merge was applied three times)

essentially like this:
https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commits/delivery-sync-rc5_resolvedv2/
instead of adding another branch merge commit, i added a commit to visualize what is happening here.

https://github.com/mbien/netbeans/commits/delicery-sync-rc5_resolved/ but this made more sense to me.

But ultimately I don't really care, whatever works is good.

FWIW: Followup RCs would have to keep doing the same trick to sync back. But this is a bit hypothetical given how late we are in the RC phase. (amending merge commits is also really easy: copy branch, change code, commit --amend the merge)
@stevaber the message log did not make it through.

@mbien I assumed from your comment elsewhere that you were going to amend the merge commit on delivery to not touch the spec version and force push it. That would also be fine. The important thing is that all commits on delivery end up in master and release240.

I don't have an issue with the different merge commits here as they tell different stories, and other times we've done this it's been fixing merge conflicts from multiple PRs. The spec version decrement increment thing isn't ideal, but then this shouldn't have been touched in the original PR or the revert PR either.

> I assumed from your comment elsewhere that you were going to amend the merge commit on delivery and force push it.

I experienced [a momentary lapse of reason](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Momentary_Lapse_of_Reason) and forgot that sync PRs don't have a branch (thats why I asked eric on slack if i should force push into his sync PR which makes no sense), they _are_ delivery. What I did instead was to use a copy of delivery as vehicle to move commits back to master.

Sure, the PR branch is delivery. It's a transient integration branch. We can force push and fix things on there when necessary, and I have multiple times. You could check with Eric and [Meddle](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meddle)  with that if you prefer.

Until the release is out, it's important to make sure the commits align or it can lead to knock on problems.

@stevaber thank you, that was helpful. Could you please do this:

1. Open the Template dialog (Tools -> Templates)
2. Choose "JavaServer Faces" -> "JSF Composite Component"
3. Choose "Open in Editor"
4. Change line 6 to (remove the space between `#else if`:
  ```freemarker
  <#elseif isJSF22?? || isJSF30??>
  ```
5. Save the file
6. Retry the generation

By doing this you replace the NB provided template with your own fixed one. To return to the NB version, just choose the template again (Step 2) and select "Revert to default".

If this fixes the problem, I'll prepare an PR for NB25.

@neilcsmith-net please advise how to fix build failure https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/12162766052/job/33936238338?pr=7979 related to signature check. There's a (formally) incompatible change on friend-only API.

![html-color-invert](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ab4ef31c-761a-4457-8567-bf22d218871a)

what you see here is the html renderer noticing that the contrast is too low and trying to fix it to set the color to the complementary white or black. This is the opposite of what the intention is since it is now highlighting the folder instead of the file.

As previously mentioned the tricky part is to make it work on different background / foregrounds - its used on different components and component states.

I reduced the fade value to 0.7f and computed it for the tabs and tabs-switcher separately, since both have different colors.

![faded-folders](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/41c7bf00-1664-48a1-b109-43b468b5099a)

Tested on all supported themes and it looks ok I think. The "same background color for same projects" mode is still not working very well, esp on dark themes, but making both decorators work well together won't be easy.

here the commit https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/c4ea2916a398a77a04c839a97398b58845c57cb5, feel free to squash it with your PR

@sdedic sorry, I'd missed that the addition was incompatible.  Am not involved with releases at the moment, and only commented after a glance at this to try and save @ebarboni some headaches post NB24.

_If_ this has to go in as is, then either wait for the API sigs to merge in a week or so and rebase, manually patch the 3 required lines into the sig file (which should pass then?), or merge and be prepared to help Eric with the API signature integration post release.

OTOH, either the test is relevant or not?  Add the methods as default on the interface, as you did in the last change to that file to not require changes to pass tests?  Or lets just stop having sigtests for friend APIs as they're irrelevant - the build will pick up internal breakage, and we don't support external usage.

Our process for handling sig tests for releases could do with a review anyway.  I have some ideas how to improve that, but we have the one we have for now.

Thanks for the suggested patch! Are you on a Windows machine yourself?

If you are trying to solve https://github.com/apache/netbeans/discussions/7051, I'd recommend the following:
1) Test the patch for a few weeks to see if the problem goes away as a result or not.
2) If the problem did indeed go away as a result of the PR, now run NetBeans with the patch off again, and verify that the problem comes back.
3) Re-introduce the patch and run it again for a while, and re-verify that the problem is gone again.

This seems to be the only way to troubleshoot this particular bug.

Here's what I usually do when I want to have multiple custom NetBeans builds available to test and switch between:
1) Clone the NetBeans repo.
git clone git@github.com:apache/netbeans.git
2) Switch to the branch of the latest official release. E.g. "git checkout 23"
3) Run "ant". (Takes a few minutes.)
4) Now there is a fresh NetBeans build in the directory netbeans
bbuild
etbeans. Copy it e.g. to "C:\Program Files\NetBeans
etbeans-23"
5) Now apply the changes you want to test.
E.g. "wget https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/netbeans/pull/8024.patch" and "patch -p1 < 8024.patch" for this PR if you have a Linux command line available (via [WSL](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install)).
6) Run "ant clean" and "ant" again.
7) Now you have another fresh NetBeans build in the directory netbeans
bbuild
etbeans. Copy it e.g. to "C:\Program Files\NetBeans
etbeans-23-pr8024"
8) Now you can run either "C:\Program Files\NetBeans
etbeans-23 in
etbeans64.exe" or "C:\Program Files\NetBeans
etbeans-23-pr8024 in
etbeans64.exe" to run with your patch disabled or enabled. (You may need to set netbeans_jdkhome to the path to your JDK in etc
etbeans.conf in each NetBeans folder.)
Sounds good

Sorry, `git rebase` did not save your authorship. Can you tell me how to get this information back?

> @mbien, thank you so much for your help! Sorry, `git rebase` did not save your authorship. Can you tell me how to get this information back?

@troizet not a problem with me. But you can add co-authors to commits by appending this to the commit message:
```
bla bla bla.

Co-authored-by: Duke <foo@mail.com>
```
https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-your-project/creating-and-editing-commits/creating-a-commit-with-multiple-authors
